title: Density - experiment to determine density of solid

content.question: A student wants to determine the density of an irregularly shaped object. The student partially fills a large graduated cylinder with water, records the initial volume <math alttext="V sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mstyle></math>, and then places the graduated cylinder on a scale and records the mass <math alttext="M sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>. The student then places the object in the water and it comes to rest on the bottom of the graduated cylinder. The student then records the mass reading on the scale, <math alttext="M sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math>, and the volume reading on the graduated cylinder, <math alttext="V sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math>. Which of the following correctly indicates a method that could be used to determine the density of the object, and provides a valid justification?

choices.label: Dividing <math alttext="M sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> by <math alttext="V sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></mstyle></math>, because density is the ratio of mass to volume.

Dividing <math alttext="M sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> by <math alttext="V sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></mstyle></math>, because the scale reading represents the mass of the object and the volume reading represents the volume of the object.

Dividing <math alttext="open parenthesis, M sub f minus M sub i, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>M</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>M</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>)</mo></math> by <math alttext="open parenthesis, V sub f minus V sub i, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>)</mo></math>, because the difference in mass is equal to the mass of the object and the difference in volume is equal to the volume of the object.

Dividing <math alttext="open parenthesis, M sub f minus M sub i, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>M</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>M</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>)</mo></math> by <math alttext="open parenthesis, V sub f minus V sub i, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>)</mo></math>, because the difference in mass represents the mass of the object and the difference in volume represents the volume of the water.

content.answer: Dividing <math alttext="open parenthesis, M sub f minus M sub i, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>M</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>M</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>)</mo></math> by <math alttext="open parenthesis, V sub f minus V sub i, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>)</mo></math>, because the difference in mass is equal to the mass of the object and the difference in volume is equal to the volume of the object.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
